Equities rallied on Monday after economic data from in China signalled a brighter outlook for the manufacturing sector in the world’s second-biggest economy.

The numbers helped ease fears about global economic growth, as investors waited for clear signs of a breakthrough in trade talks between Washington and Beijing. The improving mood survived a test from a series of purchasing managers’ indices out in Europe, with data from the US due later in the session.

BE11:16am

So, rather than paying attention to the China Take, we can turn to CS, who went on tour to the mainland last week.

BE11:17am

On the macro the expert sees China’s policy markers stuck in a trilemma until 2020 between economy growth, full employment and
financial stability with choosing one goal inevitably compromising the other two. Chinese leaders are trying hard to strike a balance, but
growth still gets higher priority. Therefore, risk aversion will probably be the keynote of macro control before 2020.

o On US/China relations the foreign affairs expert said China is buying time through negotiations, delaying a final deal and waiting for a
good opportunity like the election year so that Trump would lose patience and can also delay any implementation if a deal is struck.

o On the property market the expert expects to see 5-8% growth in property investment and ±3% growth in sales volume. We note this
compares to an increase of 13% in residential investment in 2018. We also note sales volumes are also at a low level vs housing starts.

Forecast is for flat H2 revenue per seat rather than 4% or so previously expected, which because of the fixed costs has a massive effect on earnings.

BE11:27am

Here's what happens to Numis forecasts.

Shinshin Anecdata update - I am being swamped with increasingly desperately toned email from EU villa lettings people for this summer, so maybe people are holding off to see B****t before making booking commitments.
BE11:28am

● 1H19 results broadly in line: EZJ guides to a loss before tax of £275m, broadly in line (-3%) with NSe of a £268m loss. Seat capacity increased by 14.5% yoy (NSe +15.1%) and RPS at c/FX declined by c.7.4%, in line with prior guidance of a mid-to high single digit decline, albeit slightly behind NSe of -6.4%. Headline cost per seat (CPS) at c/FX increased by 1.4%, slightly ahead of NSe of +1.1%.
● Profit warning on H2: EZJ reported that Brexit and macro uncertainty are driving weaker consumer demand across its network, particularly in the UK and Germany and over the last 2 wks. As such, Q3 yields (c.57% booked) are weaker yoy despite the benefit of the shift in the timing of Easter (c.£50m typically). So far (c.30% booked) Q4 yields are "softer than last year" (i.e. negative), but are expected to improve to positive territory as a consequence of yield optimising initiatives, ancillary growth and "a more certain Brexit outlook in the coming weeks".
● Capacity growth: EZJ has made no major changes to its capacity outlook (+10% seat growth FY19 maintained), despite the worsening demand backdrop. It retains the ability to actively manage capacity growth for winter 2019/20 down by a couple of percentage points, albeit ST orders with Airbus are relatively fixed (NSe +7.0% 1H20 seat growth).
● Estimates & valuation: Following today's update, we downgrade our FY19 PBT forecast by 27% to £415m from £569m, and FY20 by 28% to £445m from £622m. This assumes RPS at c/FX in 2H19 of +0.4% (-0.7% Q3, +1.5% Q4), at the bottom-end of the guidance range given the lack of visibility on Q4. The remainder of our forecasts are broadly unchanged, marking to market current spot fuel prices and FX, while our CPS at c/FX assumption has slightly weakened (+0.5% vs +0.2% prior). We continue to value EZJ on 12.5x FY20 P/E, therefore following our estimate changes our fair value reduces from 1,566p to 1,121p. Consequently, we downgrade from BUY to HOLD.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Same downgrade from Goodbody.

FATDAZ re airlines did everyone see that new website called escape that tracks cheap flights to and from your locations
Pharma I intend to cheer myself up (or at least avoid abject misery) by treating any news that comes out of parliament today as an elaborate April Fool's joke.
BE11:29am

We think FY19 will be closer to £400m pre-tax
The guidance update given this morning is seen as taking £100m off consensus pre-tax numbers to circa £460m, with H119 reporting a loss of circa £275m.
However, risk is still seen to the downside given that management has shifted its more positive outlook from the whole of H219 to now focus on Q419 only, but with commentary that early bookings for that period (29% sold to date) are on weaker pricing. As such, it is going to take a significant improvement in Q419 to deliver £460m and with our updated fuel bill now at £1.4bn vs £1.38bn previously, we think that pre-tax will in fact come in at £405m this year.
Pricing needs to be +2% in H219 to deliver £400m+
Looking forward to H219, the company forecasts that ‘H2 revenue per seat at constant currency is expected to be slightly up’. This will be helped by the timing of the recognition of ancillary revenues this year under IFRS15, with this expected to see 3% growth yoy in ancillary revenues per pax, with fares at +1.9%, for a combined revenue per pax of +2.1% in H2, giving -2% for FY19 overall. Ex-fuel unit costs are modelled flat yoy. As such, we see H219 pre-tax at £680m vs the £513m profit seen in H218 (£578m of profit before exceptional loss of £133m).
From Buy to Hold until tricky summer trading picture is clearer
While this morning’s adjustment to the downside was not a total surprise the quantum was larger than we had expected, and with risks to the downside to guidance we think the stock is a Hold until we get through the early part of this summer’s trading.

(@Fatdaz: doesn't Skyscanner do that also?)

Viking1 Excellent stuff BE , 1-0
BE11:32am

IAG is the 591st stock in the STOXX Europe 600 on price performance YTD, with the shares having fallen ~18%, underperforming the peers both in Europe (AF- KLM +6%; Lufthansa -1%) and the US (Delta +1%; American -4%; United -6%).

11:32 am
BE11:32am

(i) Buy side view that the profit guide for 2019 (operating profit to be in-line with 2018 at €3,230m) may be too bullish, given reliance on pax yield improvement and flat non-fuel unit costs; (ii) Confusion around the outlook for free cash post the FY18 results; (iii) Brexit-related concerns around ownership, potential weaker trading near-term, and possible structural implications for travel to/from the UK longer-term; and (iv) IAG’s exclusion from the MSCI Global Standard Cap Index.

FATDAZ @BE re skyscanner sort of the new site has a more attractive user friendly interface ...... I was an early adopter of sky scanner which sadly lost its way
BE11:33am

The MSCI point was technical. We share IAG’s confidence that its opcos will comply with the relevant rules post Brexit and think that any impacts on travel will be short-lived. The macro backdrop (3% global GDP & 6% RPK growth expected), capacity discipline from IAG and its peers, rising fuel costs, further competitor failures (eg. WOW), and decent 4Q18 exit rates on yield, all support IAG’s aim to progress pax unit revs in 2019. We assume just +30bps, with +50bps on non-fuel unit costs, and see the guidance as achievable, helped by FX. WC inflows in 2019 and lower pension payments in 2020 should allow IAG to generate FCF of €1bn (9% yield) and €1.4bn (12% yield) respectively.

BE11:33am

IAG normally trades at a premium to AF-KLM and Lufthansa thanks to superior margins & returns, but is currently broadly in line, on ~5x P/E & ~4x EV/EBITDAR for 2019. While Delta has margins (21% at EBITDAR) & returns (16% pre-tax ROIC) more in keeping with the high levels of IAG, IAG trades on a ~30% discount. At current levels, we see Brexit concerns as more than priced in, creating an opportunity. Our revised 675p TP for IAG (~7x P/E & ~5x EV/EBITDAR for 2019) implies greater than 30% potential upside, and we reiterate our Buy rating.

BE11:43am

We had anticipated most of the recent developments at Kingfisher … We have
been sceptical about the 'One Kingfisher' strategy ever since it was introduced
four years ago. We are not surprised, therefore, that consensus forecasts have
been falling steadily in recent months (down c25% since last September), that
the company appears to have effectively given up on the profit targets it set for
the strategy, or by the recent management changes.
… but there is one we didn’t expect … However we had not expected, given
these developments, that the Board would remain committed to the strategy. At
the analysts' results meeting the Chairman confirmed that the new Chief
Executive "… will come into a strategy that's clear. And accepting that, and
understanding that, and buying into it, I think will be important part of what we're
looking for".

Soundbuy ITV - notice Liberum dropping their PT this am. 240p - 190p

FATDAZ re KGF always found it notoriously difficult to trade made several strong bear cases and almost always saw the stock squeezed higher ......
11:44 am
BE11:44am

Not sure I'd read that much into the chairman failing to say, "this five year plan is confirmed to be a disaster after four years, let's try something else" ....

DRichi @AM- Thanks- will have a proper read through and see if it's worth a flutter...
BE11:44am

But Geoff's a much much much better reader of these things than me.

BE11:44am

… and this makes it hard to continue to recommend an Overweight stance on
Kingfisher. Our Overweight rating was predicated on the strategy being reversed,
and the company implementing a review of its corporate structure, under a new
CEO. As this now seems unlikely, we no longer see Sum-of-the-Parts as the most
appropriate way to value the company. We therefore revert to valuing the
company on our usual, 'as is', basis and, given its current financial performance,
this leaves little base case upside. We therefore downgrade to Equal-weight.
We are not convinced earnings have bottomed, but believe that the company
could yet change its view on strategy. Whilst the current common sourcing
strategy remains in place we believe that trading is likely to remain very poor and
that further earnings downgrades may be forthcoming - we are currently ~10%
below consensus FY20/21 adjusted PBT. However, we are not tempted to turn
Underweight, as we think a new CEO could yet still be the catalyst for a change
in strategic direction (in much the way Justin King was when he arrived at
Sainsbury in 2004). Our 420p Bull case continues to value Kingfisher on a Sumof-
the-Parts basis and implies 80% upside.

11:44 am

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 126.90, down 0.2 (-0.16%), High: 128.75, Low: 126.65, Volume: 1.85m
BE11:46am

Liberum stepping back forecasts to reflect domestic uncertainties.

BE11:46am

Anecdotally, there seems to be some suggestions that advertisers are holding back on advertising decisions until there is greater clarity on what is happening with Brexit. We this will hold back TV advertising spend and it has also coincided with advertisers such as Thomas Cook and GSK stating they are reducing their TV advertising spending to focus more on digital because it offers a greater Return on Investment. Our concern is that advertisers will look for excuses not to spend on TV until there is more clarity and that, given our view that Brexit will not be resolved satisfactorily for several months at least and there will be political uncertainty, advertising will be weak.

We therefore think ITV’s total advertising revenues will fall 3.7% yoy in 2019E (we had +1.2% previously) and that there is a risk that both March and April advertising revenues are weaker than guidance of -17% and +6% to +10% respectively, although there is a chance of governmental spending around Brexit may help alleviate some of the pain. Past-the first four months, because of the uncertain political outlook, we expect overall advertising revenues to remain weak.

Overall, we take down 2019E and 2020E adjusted EPS by 16%-17% to 13p and 15.3p respectively. Despite the downgrades, ITV is trading at less than 10x adjusted FY19E PE.

chad_john Haven't Liberum had silly price targets on ITV for a while? Coming back a bit probably doesn't mean a whole lot

11:53 am
BE11:53am

We think that expectations for WPP are now so low that even delivery of current guidance will be enough for the shares to enjoy a re-rating. If there's any indication that operations are modestly better [less bad] than the market currently factors in, then the re-rating could be more substantial.

A. M. @Pharma: Indeed, though I don't suppose that find is going to be a significant contributor.Speaking of which, I have 'Carbon Democracy' on my reading list -- I think it addresses part of that issue.

BE11:54am

To be clear, we aren’t forecasting a return to meaningful growth any time soon. With structural concerns over the industry lifting, management having set low expectations and a supportive valuation, we move to BUY. The shares are trading on a multi-year discount in terms of PE relative. With a 7% dividend yield, covered by both earnings and cash, we think downside risk is limited. Our TP is unchanged at 1,010p

BE11:54am

Or to put it another way ......

11:54 am
BE11:54am

The reasons to sell or avoid advertising agencies have been well rehearsed over the past two years. At a certain point we think the question becomes: what is the right price to pay for the world's largest marketing services company? Despite all of the operational and management issues of the recent past, WPP continues to generate £1.1bn of annual equity free cash flow, which we think is not reflected in its £10bn market capitalisation. Cynics will say that estimates are simply "the wrong numbers" given the structural and cyclical environment. We think that - absent a major macro shock - estimates have bottomed. With a supportive valuation, all that the shares need is delivery in-line with expectations and hence evidence that the business is stabilising. Any signs that trading is "less bad" and the re-rating could be more substantial.

FATDAZ @Excel interesting that the service is that long in the tooth
A. M. @Excel: apologies if I'm being simple, but doesn't the price of an add-free subscription determine the price ITV can charge from advertisers?
A. M. (ad-free there)
BE11:55am

And there's a list of blobs underneath -- leverage, management incentives, that kind of thing -- the most interesting of which are the sector wide ones.

BE11:55am

■ Although there are few signs that FMCG companies are actually
increasing their marketing spend with agencies, there are hopeful
indicators that the cuts of the past several years have bottomed out
■ Structural concerns over the industry - while widely repeated - have been
contradicted by the continued growth of the media agencies and by the
solid, uninterrupted growth of the US listed agency holding companies
(3-5% organic growth in 2018)
■ Incursion by consulting firms, or a shift to in-housing of marketing
services, are popular in the trade and financial press, but have had little
discernable effect on the numbers
■ Ultimately, marketing firms are people-based businesses and the staff
who work in one agency-holding company are not markedly different
from those employed at another, although their organisational structure
may differ. If the new WPP management can get the organisation right,
there is considerable room to close the valuation gap with peers
■ Consider that the market values each WPP employee at $150,000 (EV)
while at Interpublic and Omnicom the market values each employee
50-70% higher.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Whilst 2019 looks set to be an exciting year for Circassia, with the pending U.S. launch of Duaklir and FDA submission of AirNOvent expected in 2Q19, we believe severe cash flow issues are also likely. Following US approval of Duaklir on 29 March 2019, Circassia is now required to pay AstraZeneca (AZ) $120m including $100m for the approval and $20m in deferred consideration related to Tudorza. The payments will transform Circassia from a cash rich specialty pharma company to one heavily indebted whilst still loss making. To make matters worse, prospects for Tudorza continue to deteriorate, with AZ recently reporting 2018 U.S. revenues of the product of $25m, a 62% Y/Y decline. We maintain our NPV derived target price of the company at 20p and reiterate our Sell rating.

BE12:05pm

Whilst we continue to forecast sales of Duaklir of $120m by 2025E, the disappointing U.S. launches of two other twice daily dual bronchodilators for COPD, AZ's Bevespi and Sunovion's Utibron, raise concerns about Duaklir's sales potential. Despite being promoted by a full primary care sales force, Bevespi has only achieved sales of $40m in its second year on market, with Utibron achieving sales of c.$8m. The success of GSK's triple therapy Trelegy also means competition in the U.S. COPD market is intensifying. Circassia plans to launch Duaklir into this market with a sales force of only 200 reps, and does not expect to significantly increase marketing spend despite new product launches traditionally requiring such investment.
